document.docTitle: Wolongia tetramacroseta Wan & Peng, 2013, new species
document.masterDocTitle: The spiders of the genus Wolongia Zhu, Kim & Song, 1997 from China (Araneae: Tetragnathidae)

Etymology. The specific name comes from the combination of prefix “ tetra- ” and the Latin word “ macroseta ”, meaning “four” and “macrosetae” respectively, and refers to the two pairs of strong macrosetae locating on the cymbium; adjective.

Diagnosis. This species can be easily distinguished from other
Wolongia
species by the combination of the following characters: 1 ) brown median stripe of abdominal dorsum with wave-shaped margins (
Figs 29
A, 30 A); 2 ) the longest prolateral seta on Metatarsus I and II about as long as or slightly less than the width of Metatarsus I and II respectively (
Figs
2
I, 32 C); 3 ) femur I with several rows of short median macrosetae prolaterally and ventrally (
Figs 29
C, F; 32 A–B); 4 ) cymbium with two pairs of macrosetae (
Figs 29
E, 31 C); 5 ) cymbial base without a denticle retrolaterally; 6 ) spermatheca membranous, oval in dorsal view (
Figs 30
C, 32 E); 7 ) copulatory ducts approach spermathecae from posterior-mesal angle (
Figs 30
C, 32 E); 8 ) the distance between terminals of fertilization ducts longer than that between copulatory ducts (
Figs 30
C, 32 E). This species resembles
W. guoi
and
W. bicruris
n. sp. in short macrosetae on femur I ventrally and prolaterally (
Figs 3
C, F; 6 A–B; 15 C, F; 18 A–B; 29 C, F; 32 A–B), but differs in: 1 ) cymbium with four macrosetae versus absent in the latters; 2 ) absence of a pair of inverted “V”-shaped plates in ventral view of atria which is present in
W. guoi
(
Figs 16
C, 18 D); 3 ) spermatheca membranous versus strongly sclerotized in
W. bicruris
n. sp. (
Figs 4
D, 6 F).

Description. Male ( holotype ): Total length 2.05 . Cephalothorax 1.05 long, 0.85 wide. Abdomen 1.21 long, 0.91 wide. Carapace yellowish brown, with slightly dark margins. AME 0.08 , ALE 0.08 , PME 0.09 , PLE 0.09 , AME-AME=AME-ALE ( 0.05 ), PME-PME>PME-PLE ( 0.07 > 0.06 ), LMOA 0.22 , AWMOA 0.18 , PWMOA 0.21 . Clypeus 0.12 . Chelicerae yellowish brown, with 5 retromarginal teeth (
Figs
1
I, 31 D). Labium dark-brown, width 0.25 , length 0.15 . Coxae brown. Legs yellow-brown. Femur I with one dorsal longer macroseta and several rows of shorter median macrosetae prolaterally and ventrally (
Figs 29
C, F; 32 A–B). Leg measurements: I 5.35 ( 1.59 , 1.83 , 1.35 , 0.58 ), II 3.93 ( 1.22 , 1.25 , 0.97 , 0.49 ), III 2.29 ( 0.73 , 0.70 , 0.51 , 0.35 ), IV 3.20 ( 1.06 , 1.05 , 0.78 , 0.40 ). Abdomen oval, widest medially. Dorsum silvery-white, with a brown longitudinal median stripe with wave-shaped margined (
Fig. 29
A). Venter brown, with several pairs of white spots. Cymbium with two pairs of strong macrosetae (the pair near cmp longer than the other pair at the top of cba;
Figs 29
E, 31 C); conductor with long and thin terminal (
Figs 29
B, 31 A).

Female ( paratype ): Total length 2.40 . Cephalothorax 0.95 long, 0.80 wide. Abdomen 1.71 long, 1.36 wide. General appearance and patterns as in male, but femur I without rows of short macrosetae prolaterally and ventrally. Leg measurements: I 4.18 ( 1.10 , 1.34 , 1.09 , 0.65 ), II 3.20 ( 0.90 , 1.02 , 0.80 , 0.48 ), III 1.92 ( 0.56 , 0.58 , 0.41 , 0.37 ), IV 2.80 ( 0.87 , 0.89 , 0.63 , 0.41 ). Brown median stripe of the dorsal abdomen narrower anteriorly, wider posteriorly (
Fig. 30
A). Epigynum with larger atrium (
Figs 30
B, 32 D); spermathecae membranous, suboval in dorsal view (
Figs 30
C, 32 E).
Variation. Males, total length 1.78–2.15 (n= 7 ); females, total length 2.13–2.53 (n= 42 ).
